Description: Limestone seated statue of Meri: this statue shows Meri with short, cropped hair and a simple pleated kilt, resting his open left hand and his fisted right hand on his thighs. The cropped hair on this statue is often found on representations of middle-aged men. But there are no other signs of age: the pleated kilt is appropriate to a young man, and the position of the hands is found on representations of both young and older men. There is hieroglyphic text at the front of the plinth.
Curator's comments: This statue is one of a pair made for the tomb of Meri. The two (very likely the work of the same sculptor) are almost identical in many respects. Both are the same size; both show Meri seated. The other statue (1902,0412.214) has short, curly hair, a kilt of 'shendyt' type, and arms crossed over the chest. Bibliography: B. Porter & R.
